sections.heading: Quo warranto; refusal of Attorney General to institute
sections.text: 80.02Quo warranto; control of Attorney General over certain proceedings.80.031Procedure.80.032Judgment of ouster.80.04Quo warranto; effect of judgment.

sections.heading: Quo warranto; control of Attorney General over certain proceedings.
sections.text: warranto; control of Attorney General over certain proceedings.

sections.heading: Procedure
sections.text: 80.031 Procedure.—The rules about pleading and procedure in mandamus apply to actions for quo warranto as near as may be.

sections.heading: Judgment of ouster.
sections.text: 80.032 Judgment of ouster.—When any petition is well-founded, a judgment of ouster may issue without further amendments to the extent that the petition is well-founded. History.—s. 30, ch. 67-254. sections.heading: Quo warranto; effect of judgment.
sections.text: 80.04 Quo warranto; effect of judgment.—When an individual institutes an action without the consent of the Attorney General, the judgment is conclusive as between the parties other than the state. The judgment is not a bar to any quo warranto by the state nor shall a judgment instituted by the Attorney General be a bar to actions by any claimant other than the parties thereto. The party receiving judgment shall be entitled to exercise the office until removed by quo warranto or until his or her rights thereto shall otherwise cease. History.—s. 3, ch. 1874, 1872; RS 1783; GS 2260; RGS 3583; CGL 5448; s. 30, ch. 67-254; s. 421, ch. 95-147.
